name: transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO1 | transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO1 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21162/documentation

This dataset represents the transport of one metric ton.km of freight in South Africa by a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry of Euro 1 emission standard. The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle, including the production and maintenance of the vehicle, the transportation of goods and the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of the road pavement. The scope of the dataset is the operation of the vehicle, which has inputs of vehicle production, vehicle maintenance, and road pavement construction, maintenance and operation, via linking to global datasets (i.e. the equipment and infrastructure datasets are not South African-specific). The dataset represents the average 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry of Euro 1 emission standard vehicle within South Africa and is therefore an average across both petrol and diesel vehicles (i.e. the dataset represents the average of the entire fleet and shows the fuel use, both in terms of petrol and diesel, for the movement of a tonne.km of freight).   ;The average freight load of a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry is 3.9 tonnes, with an average freight load factor of 50% (both values calculated from SATIM model (ERC, 2015), which used factors from the Road Freight Association's vehicle cost schedule and calibrated these values to the 2014 tonne.kms reported by the Department of Logistics at the University of Stellenbosch. The load factor accounts for all transport trips). The average gross vehicle mass (GVW) is 7.1 tonnes (calculated from freight loading and that freight accounts for 55% of GVW in a heavy commercial vehicle (DoT,2009).; The dataset is not parameterised and factors cannot be changed by users.;Fuel consumption and the primary emissions (nitrogen oxides, nitrous oxide, methane, non-methane hydrocarbons, ammonia, benzene and lead) are modelled based on information and assumptions on fleet mixes and usage of vehicles in different road and traffic situations. Basic emission data is taken from HBEFA 3.4. (INFRAS, 2017), with extensive weighted averaging of vehicles in different traffic situations performed (see report for parameters applied and data sources for road and traffic conditions in South Africa). Emission factors for sulphur dioxide and for carbon dioxide are not taken directly from HBEFA but are calculated using the carbon content and the sulphur content of diesel and petrol in South Africa (and the fuel consumption). Heavy metal emissions to air (other than lead) are extrapolated from "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3" on the basis of diesel consumption and "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" on the basis of petrol consumption. Emissions arising from wear of tyres, brakes and road are calculated from the applicable global datasets ("treatment of tyre/brake/road wear emissions, lorry, GLO, 2013") on the basis of GVW and freight loading.     ;Vehicle production and maintenance is described in the individual global datasets. Vehicle demand per tonne.km is calculated based on the lifetime kilometric performance, taken from Spielmann et al., (2007) (540,000 km for a heavy commercial vehicle), and the average freight load. The average freight load is calculated from the SATIM model (ERC, 2015), weighted to account for the current commercial vehicle fleet in South Africa (eNaTIS, 2017). Road construction, maintenance and disposal, and road operation are described in the individual global datasets. Road demand per tonne.km is calculated based on weighted road usage of each vehicle type of the road network in South Africa (see report for calculations and data sources). ;References: ;INFRAS (2017) Handbook Emission Factors for Road Transport (HBEFA) 3.4. INFRAS, Bern, Switzerland; ;eNaTIS (2018) Vehicle population statistics for December 2017/January 2018, Electronic National Administration Traffic Information System (eNaTIS): Pretoria, SA.; ;ERC (2015) South African TIMES Model (SATIM) Energy Research Centre - University of Cape Town: Cape Town, SA.; ;Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.;                                                        DoT (2009) National Transport Master Plan: The Implications of Global Oil Depletion for Transport Systems in South Africa. Department of Transport. Pretoria, SA.

The scope of this dataset is the operation of the vehicle, with inputs of vehicle and road infrastructure. The transportation service starts with the demand for fuel (diesel and petrol) and the requirement for construction and maintenance of the vehicle and road infrastructure.

The dataset ends with the service of transporting freight 1 metric ton.km (tonnage includes the weight of items and any packaging/housing). The dataset includes the operation of an average light commercial vehicle and links to the production and maintenance of one average light commercial vehicle. It also links to the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of road pavement. The dataset includes the consumption of fuel (diesel and petrol), emissions to air and operational wear emissions.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport/4923:Freight transport by road

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are representative of vehicle fleet and road freight data for 2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Fuel consumption and primary emissions (nitrogen oxides, nitrous oxide, methane, non-methane hydrocarbons, ammonia, benzene and lead) are based on fleet composition and usage of vehicles in different road and traffic situations in South Africa (see report for parameters applied and data sources for road and traffic conditions in South Africa). Basic emission data is taken from HBEFA 3.4. (INFRAS, 2017) for the emission standard relevant to South Africa, and with weighted averaging of vehicles reflecting the different traffic situations in South Africa. Sulphur dioxide and carbon dioxide emissions reflect the sulphur and carbon content of fuels in South Africa. Heavy metal emissions to air (other than lead) and wear emissions (tyre, break and road) are not South African specific or emission-standard relevant (i.e. are extrapolated from a Euro 3 global transport dataset of the same vehicle. Equipment and infrastructure datasets are not South African specific.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The dataset reflects current technology in that the calculations apply current/recent road infrastructure, commercial vehicle fleet and road freight data for South Africa. The calculations also reflect current fuel quality and emission standards in South Africa.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Emissions of heavy metals to air are extrapolated from global dataset on the basis of fuel consumption. Wear emissions are extrapolated from global lorry wear treatment datasets on the basis of GVW and load factor. Dataset utilises global emission factors and emission factors based on European data.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is calculated using the South African TIMES Model (SATIM) (ERC, 2015), total South African vehicle fleet in 2017 (eNaTIS, 2017) and road freight  data (Havenga et al., 2016; CSIR, 2013) as principal data sources.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     References: ERC (2015) South African TIMES Model. Energy Research Centre, University of Cape Town; eNaTIS (2017) Live Vehicle Population. Electronic National Administration Traffic Information System; Havenga, J., Simpson, Z., King, D., de Bod, A. and Braun, M. (2016) Logistics Barometer South Africa 2016, Stellenbosch University: Stellenbosch, SA.; CSIR (2013) 10th Annual State of Logistics Survey for South Africa, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR): Pretoria, SA.

exchanges.description: Extrapolated from the "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3, GLO, 2013" dataset using diesel consumption and the "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" dataset using petrol consumption (i.e. the emissions from diesel and petrol consumption are extrapolated separately and summed together). The global lorry dataset uses a literature value from EMEP/EEA (2013), while the global passenger car dataset uses literature values from Europe. Reference: Ntziachristos, L., Samaras, Z., Kouridis, C., Hassel, D., McCrae, I., Hickman, J., Zierock, K-H., Keller, M., Andre, M., Winther, M., Gorissen, N., Boulter, P., Katsis, P., Joumard, R., Rijkeboer, R., Geivanidis, S., Hausberger, S. (2013) Exhaust emissions from road transport, EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2013, Copenhagen, European Commission.

Extrapolated from the "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3, GLO, 2013" dataset using diesel consumption and the "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" dataset using petrol consumption (i.e. the emissions from diesel and petrol consumption are extrapolated separately and summed together). The global lorry dataset uses a literature value from EMEP/EEA (2013), while the global passenger car dataset uses literature values from Europe. Reference: Ntziachristos, L., Samaras, Z., Kouridis, C., Hassel, D., McCrae, I., Hickman, J., Zierock, K-H., Keller, M., Andre, M., Winther, M., Gorissen, N., Boulter, P., Katsis, P., Joumard, R., Rijkeboer, R., Geivanidis, S., Hausberger, S. Extrapolated from the "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3, GLO, 2013" dataset using diesel consumption and the "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" dataset using petrol consumption (i.e. the emissions from diesel and petrol consumption are extrapolated separately and summed together). The global lorry dataset uses a literature value from EMEP/EEA (2013), while the global passenger car dataset uses literature values from Europe. Reference: Ntziachristos, L., Samaras, Z., Kouridis, C., Hassel, D., McCrae, I., Hickman, J., Zierock, K-H., Keller, M., Andre, M., Winther, M., Gorissen, N., Boulter, P., Katsis, P., Joumard, R., Rijkeboer, R., Geivanidis, S., Hausberger, S. (2013) Exhaust emissions from road transport, EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2013, Copenhagen, European Commission..

Sulphur dioxide emissions per tonne.km is calculated from fuel use and the sulphur content of fuels (SAPIA, 2015). Sulphur content in South African fuels is 500 ppm for petrol and a mixture of 500 ppm (73%) and 50 ppm (27%) for diesel (DoE, 2017). Fuel use per tonne.km is calculated using HBEFA 3.4 (INFRAS, 2017) modelling data and current South Africa road infrastructure, commercial vehicle fleet and road freight data. The road infrastructure data is based on the total length of paved and unpaved roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), pavement condition of national and provincial roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), road gradients (calculated from DoT (2018) data) and prevailing traffic flow (PBS-SA, 2015; Havenga & Pienaar, 2012). Changes in fuel use due to pavement type and condition are calculated according to du Plessis et al. (1990). The commercial vehicle fleet is based on total vehicle fleet data for 2017 (eNaTIS, 2017) and SATIM model data (ERC, 2015), which includes data on the breakdown of the vehicle fleet into size classes, average freight payloads, annual mileage, annual mileage decay, historic sales and scrapping factors. Freight payloads account for 51% and 55% of gross vehicle weights (GVW) for light commercial vehicles (LVC) and heavy commercial vehicles respectively in South Africa (DoT, 2009), which is used to correlate the average freight payloads with the GVW categories in ecoinvent. Commercial vehicles are split into relevant emission classes based on Thambiran & Diab (2011) and the fact that all vehicles sold since 2006 have been of a Euro2 standard (Nare & Kamakate, 2017; SAPIA, 2015). Maximum vehicle speeds are determined from road legislation (ArriveAlive, 2018) and vehicle legislation (Business Tech, 2016). Road freight data is calculated from the commercial vehicle fleet and SATIM data. This road freight is split into categories (major "corridor" freight, rural and urban) based on previous road freight studies (Havenga et al., 2016). This is used to determine average transport distance (CSIR, 2013) and to make various assumptions on the freight transport performed by different truck classes. These assumptions are based on the fact that larger vehicles are used to transport freight on major "corridors", while urban freight is transported using lighter vehicles.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     References: INFRAS (2017) Handbook Emission Factors for Road Transport (HBEFA) 3.4. INFRAS, Bern, Switzerland; Kannemeyer, L. Extrapolated from the "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3, GLO, 2013" dataset using diesel consumption and the "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" dataset using petrol consumption (i.e. the emissions from diesel and petrol consumption are extrapolated separately and summed together). The global lorry dataset uses a literature value from EMEP/EEA (2013), while the global passenger car dataset uses literature values from Europe. Reference: Ntziachristos, L., Samaras, Z., Kouridis, C., Hassel, D., McCrae, I., Hickman, J., Zierock, K-H., Keller, M., Andre, M., Winther, M., Gorissen, N., Boulter, P., Katsis, P., Joumard, R., Rijkeboer, R., Geivanidis, S., Hausberger, S. (2013) Exhaust emissions from road transport, EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2013, Copenhagen, European Commission.

Calculated value for the demand of road infrastructure construction, maintenance and disposal to fulfill one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the total tonne.kms of all vehicles on South African roads and the relative shares, weighted according to gross tonne.kms, of each vehicle type. Net transport performance is calculated from the current South African vehicle fleet (eNaTIS, 2017) and SATIM model annual mileage and average loading data (ERC, 2015). Net vehicle weights for freight vehicles are calculated from average load data (ERC, 2015; eNaTIS, 2017) and the percentage (51% for LCV and 55% for HCV) of a vehicles gross weight due to freight in South Africa (DoT, 2009). Net vehicle weights for passenger vehicles are taken from Spielmann et al. (2007) and from Toyota Hi-Ace data for minibus taxis (Toyota, 2018). Gross vehicle masses are calculated as the sum of net vehicle masses and loadings and used to calculate the total gross tonne.kms per vehicle type. Gross tonne.kms are used to estimate the demand of the total road network kilometers (Kannemeyer, 2016) for each vehicle type.                                                                                                         References: Kannemeyer, L. (2016) South African Road Network Condition, Needs and Funding, South African National Roads Agency (SANRAL): Pretoria, SA.; eNaTIS (2018) Vehicle population statistics for December 2017/January 2018, Electronic National Administration Traffic Information System (eNaTIS): Pretoria, SA.; ERC (2015) South African TIMES Model (SATIM) Energy Research Centre - University of Cape Town: Cape Town, SA.; DoT (2009) National Transport Master Plan: The Implications of Global Oil Depletion for Transport Systems in South Africa, Department of Transport: Pretoria, SA.; Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. Wear emissions are calaculated from the lorry brake wear emissions per GVW (8.13E-9 kg / kg GVW*km) presented in "treatment of brake wear emissions, lorry, GLO, 2013" dataset. The dataset uses wear emissions for lorries from EMEP/EEA (2013), scaled based on average gross vehicle weight and average freight load factor. The average load factor of a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry is 3.9 tonnes (calculated from SATIM model (ERC, 2015)), while the average gross vehicle mass (GVW) is 7.1 tonnes (calculated from load factor and data that freight accounts for 55% of GVW in heavy commercial vehicles (DoT, 2009)). exchanges.description: Extrapolated from the "transport, freight, lorry 3.5-7.5 metric ton, EURO3, GLO, 2013" dataset using diesel consumption and the "transport, passenger car, large size, petrol, EURO3, GLO, 2012" dataset using petrol consumption (i.e. the emissions from diesel and petrol consumption are extrapolated separately and summed together). The global lorry dataset uses a literature value from EMEP/EEA (2013), while the global passenger car dataset uses literature values from Europe. Reference: Ntziachristos, L., Samaras, Z., Kouridis, C., Hassel, D., McCrae, I., Hickman, J., Zierock, K-H., Keller, M., Andre, M., Winther, M., Gorissen, N., Boulter, P., Katsis, P., Joumard, R., Rijkeboer, R., Geivanidis, S., Hausberger, S. (2013) Exhaust emissions from road transport, EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2013, Copenhagen, European Commission.

Methane emissions per tonne.km is calculated using HBEFA 3.4 (INFRAS, 2017) modelling data and current South Africa road infrastructure, commercial vehicle fleet and road freight data. The road infrastructure data is based on the total length of paved and unpaved roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), pavement condition of national and provincial roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), road gradients (calculated from DoT (2018) data) and prevailing traffic flow (PBS-SA, 2015; Havenga & Pienaar, 2012). The commercial vehicle fleet is based on total vehicle fleet data for 2017 (eNaTIS, 2017) and SATIM model data (ERC, 2015), which includes data on the breakdown of the vehicle fleet into size classes, average freight payloads, annual mileage, annual mileage decay, historic sales and scrapping factors. Freight payloads account for 51% and 55% of gross vehicle weights (GVW) for light commercial vehicles (LVC) and heavy commercial vehicles respectively in South Africa (DoT, 2009), which is used to correlate the average freight payloads with the GVW categories in ecoinvent. Commercial vehicles are split into relevant emission classes based on Thambiran & Diab (2011) and the fact that all vehicles sold since 2006 have been of a Euro2 standard (Nare & Kamakate, 2017; SAPIA, 2015). Maximum vehicle speeds are determined from road legislation (ArriveAlive, 2018) and vehicle legislation (Business Tech, 2016). Road freight data is calculated from the commercial vehicle fleet and SATIM data. This road freight is split into categories (major "corridor" freight, rural and urban) based on previous road freight studies (Havenga et al., 2016). This is used to determine average transport distance (CSIR, 2013) and to make various assumptions on the freight transport performed by different truck classes. These assumptions are based on the fact that larger vehicles are used to transport freight on major "corridors", while urban freight is transported using lighter vehicles.                                                                                    References: INFRAS (2017) Handbook Emission Factors for Road Transport (HBEFA) 3.4. INFRAS, Bern, Switzerland; Kannemeyer, L. Calculated value for the demand of a 16 metric ton lorry to fulfill one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the lifetime kilometric performance of a HCV (540,000 km) (Spielmann et al., 2007) and the average freight load (3.9 tonne) of a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry in South Africa. The average freight load is calculated from SATIM model data (ERC, 2015), weighted to account for the current commercial vehicle fleet (eNaTIS, 2017). The 16 metric ton lorry production dataset accounts for the production of a 6.8 net tonne lorry, which most closely matches the 3.2 tonne net weight of a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry in South Africa (ERC, 2015; eNaTIS, 2017; DoT, 2009).                                                                                                     References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0. ecoinvent association. Zurich, Switzerland.; eNaTIS (2018) Vehicle population statistics for December 2017/January 2018, Electronic National Administration Traffic Information System (eNaTIS): Pretoria, SA.; ERC (2015) South African TIMES Model (SATIM) Energy Research Centre - University of Cape Town: Cape Town, SA.; DoT (2009) National Transport Master Plan: The Implications of Global Oil Depletion for Transport Systems in South Africa, Department of Transport: Pretoria, SA

exchanges.description: Diesel use per tonne.km is calculated using HBEFA 3.4 (INFRAS, 2017) modelling data and current South Africa road infrastructure, commercial vehicle fleet and road freight data. Standard diesel (500 ppm) accounts for 73% of commercial diesel use, based on the assumption that all diesel sold to retail customers is low-sulphur (50 ppm) grade and diesel sales data (DoE, 2017). The road infrastructure data is based on the total length of paved and unpaved roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), pavement condition of national and provincial roads (Kannemeyer, 2016), road gradients (calculated from DoT (2018) data) and prevailing traffic flow (PBS-SA, 2015; Havenga & Pienaar, 2012). Changes in fuel use due to pavement type and condition are calculated according to du Plessis et al. (1990). The commercial vehicle fleet is based on total vehicle fleet data for 2017 (eNaTIS, 2017) and SATIM model data (ERC, 2015), which includes data on the breakdown of the vehicle fleet into size classes, average freight payloads, annual mileage, annual mileage decay, historic sales and scrapping factors. Freight payloads account for 51% and 55% of gross vehicle weights (GVW) for light commercial vehicles (LVC) and heavy commercial vehicles respectively in South Africa (DoT, 2009), which is used to correlate the average freight payloads with the GVW categories in ecoinvent.  Commercial vehicles are split into relevant emission classes based on Thambiran & Diab (2011) and the fact that all vehicles sold since 2006 have been of a Euro2 standard (Nare & Kamakate, 2017; SAPIA, 2015). Maximum vehicle speeds are determined from road legislation (ArriveAlive, 2018) and vehicle legislation (Business Tech, 2016). Road freight data is calculated from the commercial vehicle fleet and SATIM data. This road freight is split into categories (major "corridor" freight, rural and urban) based on previous road freight studies (Havenga et al., 2016). This is used to determine average transport distance (CSIR, 2013) and to make various assumptions on the freight transport performed by different truck classes. These assumptions are based on the fact that larger vehicles are used to transport freight on major "corridors", while urban freight is transported using lighter vehicles.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     References: INFRAS (2017) Handbook Emission Factors for Road Transport (HBEFA) 3.4. INFRAS, Bern, Switzerland; Kannemeyer, L. Calculated value for the demand of road operation and maintenance (lighting, weed control, line marking etc.) to fulfill one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the total tonne.kms of all vehicles on South African roads and the relative shares, weighted according to vehicle.kms, of each vehicle type. Net transport performance is calculated from the current South African vehicle fleet (eNaTIS, 2017) and SATIM model annual mileage and average loading data (ERC, 2015). Total vehicle kilometers are used to estimate the demand of the total road network kilometers (Kannemeyer, 2016) for each vehicle type.                                                                                                         References: Kannemeyer, L. (2016) South African Road Network Condition, Needs and Funding, South African National Roads Agency (SANRAL): Pretoria, SA.; eNaTIS (2018) Vehicle population statistics for December 2017/January 2018, Electronic National Administration Traffic Information System (eNaTIS): Pretoria, SA.; ERC (2015) South African TIMES Model (SATIM) Energy Research Centre - University of Cape Town: Cape Town, SA.

Commercial vehicles are split into relevant emission classes based on Thambiran & Diab (2011) and the fact that all vehicles sold since 2006 have been of a Euro2 standard (Nare & Kamakate, 2017; SAPIA, 2015). Maximum vehicle speeds are determined from road legislation (ArriveAlive, 2018) and vehicle legislation (Business Tech, 2016). Road freight data is calculated from the commercial vehicle fleet and SATIM data. This road freight is split into categories (major "corridor" freight, rural and urban) based on previous road freight studies (Havenga et al., 2016). This is used to determine average transport distance (CSIR, 2013) and to make various assumptions on the freight transport performed by different truck classes. These assumptions are based on the fact that larger vehicles are used to transport freight on major "corridors", while urban freight is transported using lighter vehicles. Wear emissions are calaculated from the lorry tyre wear emissions per GVW (8.055E-8 kg / kg GVW*km) presented in "treatment of tyre wear emissions, lorry, GLO, 2013" dataset. The dataset uses wear emissions for lorries from EMEP/EEA (2013), scaled based on average gross vehicle weight and average freight load factor. The average load factor of a 3.5-7.5 metric ton lorry is 3.9 tonnes (calculated from SATIM model (ERC, 2015)), while the average gross vehicle mass (GVW) is 7.1 tonnes (calculated from load factor and data that freight accounts for 55% of GVW in heavy commercial vehicles (DoT, 2009)).
